Last year Kuba joined a fantastic rockstar development team at ABB. Since then he has been invited to a few conferences with his various talks and has delivered a number of presentations at user group meetups. Being passionate about sharing knowledge and meeting like-minded IT folk, he is also taking part in the preparations for the next edition of DevDay - one of the best programmer conferences in Poland. When he manages to finally get away from the keyboard, Kuba can often be seen riding a bike while listening to audiobooks (lately 'Metro 2034'). You can find him on twitter (@kubawalinski). He has also recently launched his blog at http://blog.kubawalinski.com/.

proposal.title: Aurelia - welcome to the future of JavaScript frameworks
proposal.description: With the adoption of ES6 fast approaching and even more ambitious plans for JavaScript as we move forward (thanks to the exciting new features in ES7 and beyond), it seems to be a good time to evaluate the tools that we use for our front-end development. Aurelia - a new framework from Rob Eisenberg, the creator of Durandal and a former core member of the Angular team - shows us a glimpse of the future. A future where our framework is forward thinking (using ES6 and ES7 language features), ready to cooperate with Web Components and manages to seamlessly integrate into our development workflow. Come and see the future. It’s happening now!

author.bio: Kuba developed his passion for computing at an early age, playing Tetris and Civilization on the family's PC. He started coding in middle school, when he got his hands on a copy of Visual Studio and started playing with VB6. Then he went on discovering other programming languages: Pascal, C, C++, Java, PHP, Prolog, C#, JavaScript & Python. Though Kuba spent most of his 7+ year career as an ASP.NET/C# developer, for the past few months he's taken a deep dive in the (fascinating) world of JavaScript and is currently doing his best to earn the title of a JS Ninja. Having worked in a number of very different work environments (startup, small enterprise, big corporation), Kuba benefits from being able to approach programming challenges from different perspectives. Last year Kuba joined a fantastic rockstar development team at ABB. Since then he has been invited to a few conferences with his various talks and has delivered a number of presentations at user group meetups. Being passionate about sharing knowledge and meeting like-minded IT folk, he is also taking part in the preparations for the next edition of DevDay - one of the best programmer conferences in Poland. When he manages to finally get away from the keyboard, Kuba can often be seen riding a bike while listening to audiobooks (lately 'Metro 2034'). You can find him on twitter (@kubawalinski). He has also recently launched his blog at http://blog.kubawalinski.com/.

proposal.title: Getting Into the Zero Downtime Deployment World with HTTP Applications
proposal.description: Continuous delivery is a huge step forward in our ability to rapidly deliver features and value to the users of distributed HTTP applications, but it comes with a cost and a responsibility. Most modern web applications need to be highly available, and this also means that it should be up during the deployments. This obviously goes for HTTP based services, too (a.k.a. RESTful APIs). In these cases, dealing with zero-downtime deployments is a challenge, and there is no easy solution to this challenge. Moreover, the solutions available vary based on the number of integrated clients, which parts of the World it addresses, how many active users it has... Isn't there a simple way to figure out how to get there? Join me to get into the details of the key steps on your path to zero downtime deployments. Learn about the patterns, practices and techniques that make it easier, such as incremental deployments, applying semantic versioning to HTTP applications and blue/green deployments. We'll also walk through an end-to-end demo of how a high traffic web application can survive the challenge of deployments. What seemed insurmountable at the start of the session will be practical and applicable by the time we're finished, and you should be able to see how to start moving your production application close to the zero-downtime gold standard.

author.bio: I am a web guy, Microsoft MVP and software developer specialized mainly on .NET Web technologies. I've worked at the tourism industry to build tourism software services and products for long time and now, I am working at Redgate Software as a Software Engineer helping people do database delivery in a joyful way. I am also a very involved member in the community and try my way to expose my knowledge to others through my blog, webcasts, authoring books, giving talks on various topics and so on. I live in lovely and green Cambridge, UK and I am married to a lovely woman.

proposal.title: OData v4: the easy way of exposing and querying structured data
proposal.description: The REST architectural style is the currently most appreciated way to structure a backend for several good reasons. On the other side, there are many cases where you may want just to expose data using the classical CRUD. Furthermore, the nature of REST is schema-less that is an advantage from a versioning standpoint but it can be harder to browse for many clients. In this session, we will start discussing OData vs REST, then examine the v4 OASIS standard and dig into many samples and tools to rapidly start coding OData services.

author.bio: Raffaele Rialdi is a senior Software Architect working as a consultant, speaker and trainer. Since 2003, he is a Microsoft MVP in the Developer Security category. His passion for the community brought him to be member of the board of UGIdotNET, president of DotNetLiguria and co-founder of the Italian C++ user group. Currently he is working as architect and developer on the backend of an enterprise project and working on cross-platform mobile development in both C# and C++ languages.

proposal.title: Asp.net 5 security 101
proposal.description: Asp.net 5 is not just a new release of the famous web framework but a real turning point which every developer should take care of. While cross-platform and open-source looks like just buzzwords, they are really impacting the architecture of web applications and security is certainly a fundamental part. In this session, after a brief overview of the Asp.net 5 architecture, we will see which options we have to protect our application and web apis.

author.bio: Raffaele Rialdi is a senior Software Architect working as a consultant, speaker and trainer. Since 2003, he is a Microsoft MVP in the Developer Security category. His passion for the community brought him to be member of the board of UGIdotNET, president of DotNetLiguria and co-founder of the Italian C++ user group. Currently he is working as architect and developer on the backend of an enterprise project and working on cross-platform mobile development in both C# and C++ languages.

proposal.title: Devide and Conquer - the secrets behind Role Based Access Control with Azure AD
proposal.description: Azure is taking speed into the fast pace world of X-as-a-Service. With more than dozen of services, it may quickly become a nightmare for administrators to manage. In this session we will take a look at the Role Based Access Control with Azure AD and in particular with the new Azure Portal. Join this session to understand how RBAC works and to see how to fine-grane controlls over your Azure Resources - who can do what?

author.bio: Anton has more than 13 years of professional experience. He works with Microsoft Azure since October 2008 when it was first announced and holds Microsoft MVP reward in the field of Azure since April’2011. Currently serving as a Solutions Architect for Smarthouse Media GmbH, leader on the German software market delivering oslutions for the Financial Industry. Anton is always happy to talk about Cloud.

proposal.title: Claim, Token, Who are you?!
proposal.description: We live in a 21st Century. Every person on the planet has a social accouint. Event pets have Facebook Profile. And if you are going to create the next big thing, one thing is sure - do not ask your users to create and manage password credentials with you! Just use what is already there. Claims and tokens have been there for a while, but just recently become more popular. Join this session to learn that there is not better thing than a claim and forget about password management in every application.

author.bio: Anton has more than 13 years of professional experience. He works with Microsoft Azure since October 2008 when it was first announced and holds Microsoft MVP reward in the field of Azure since April’2011. Currently serving as a Solutions Architect for Smarthouse Media GmbH, leader on the German software market delivering oslutions for the Financial Industry. Anton is always happy to talk about Cloud.

proposal.title: A lap around OpenID Connect with OWIN and KATANA
proposal.description: There are a lot of sessions about security, claims and tokens. But the examples are usually focused around one concrete Identity Provider. In this code-oriented session we will check as many OpenID Connect certified Identity Management solutions as possible, so you can choose the one that you like the most

author.bio: Anton has more than 13 years of professional experience. He works with Microsoft Azure since October 2008 when it was first announced and holds Microsoft MVP reward in the field of Azure since April’2011. Currently serving as a Solutions Architect for Smarthouse Media GmbH, leader on the German software market delivering oslutions for the Financial Industry. Anton is always happy to talk about Cloud.

proposal.title: And you can do this with ADAL?
proposal.description: ADAL, or Active Directory Authentication Library is  the one stop shop for your Authentication scenarios with Active Directory. A mature product which helps you, the developer, to integrate with Active Directory - On Premises or in Azure, regardless of the platform you are working on. Literally. Join this session to see the power of ADAL and to be surprised from the vast number of platforms it supports.

author.bio: Anton has more than 13 years of professional experience. He works with Microsoft Azure since October 2008 when it was first announced and holds Microsoft MVP reward in the field of Azure since April’2011. Currently serving as a Solutions Architect for Smarthouse Media GmbH, leader on the German software market delivering oslutions for the Financial Industry. Anton is always happy to talk about Cloud.

proposal.title: What is Scalability and why you should write a scalable application
proposal.description: Everywhere in IT we hear about scalability, but what is scalability and why your software should be scalable? What are the benefits you can get from a scalable architecture? We will discuss on pros and cons of scalable architecture inside this talk.

author.bio: Andrea is a programmer specialized in problem solving related to  application development, with focus in web applications, service oriented applications and mobile application.. Thanks to the experience earned in the latest years, Andrea is now focused on technologies like ASP.NET MVC, Xamarin, Azure. Thanks to his passion Microsoft granted him the MVP Award in Azure technology. Is a member and speaker of OrangeDotNet, the sicilian .net Community. He participated as a speaker in different events. Away from keybord he's often on a motorcycle.

proposal.title: Get more than a cache back! The Microsoft Azure (Redis) Cache
proposal.description: The Microsoft Azure Redis Cache must be the fourth or fifth generation of a hosted cache service on Azure. This time, an open-source solution has been embraced: Redis. In this session, we’ll see that it’s more than just an in-memory cache system we can use in our applications. Let’s explore what Redis is, what the different data types are and why we should care. And once we grasp how Redis stores its stuff, we’ll delve into how we can use it to its fullest extent: searching the key-value store, transactions, pub/sub support and scripting.

author.bio: Maarten Balliauw works at Microsoft. His interests are mainly web applications developed in ASP.NET (C#) or PHP and the Microsoft Azure cloud platform. Maarten also co-founded MyGet, hosting private NuGet, npm and Bower feeds for teams.

proposal.title: IoT beyond the hype - Service Assisted Communication
proposal.description: IoT enables companies to improve operational efficiency by monitoring and tracking devices. It enables them to collect and analyse device data to discover patterns and to do predictive analytics or to combine this device data with other information to power new services and revenue streams. However, a few hurdles have to be taken: how do you address these (potentially mobile and/or occasionally connected) devices? How do you deal with sparse connectivity? How do you keep your device and your communication secure? And last but not least: how do you deal with thousands or hopefully millions of concurrently active devices that require a bi-directional communication channel? In this session Stijn talks about how you can address these challenges with the Service Assisted Communication pattern

author.bio: Stijn is a software consultant from Belgium with more than 10 years experience. Over the last years he worked in oil and gas, home automation and mobility as developer and solution architect. Besides his interest in automation and IoT, he's also an active member of the DDD community and one of the founders of DDDBE

proposal.title: Your web app ever up-to-date? Go continuous delivery
proposal.description: One dream of every web developer is to have his web app ever up-to-date without a lot of effort. In this session we will see how it is possible to achieve this goal using the tools that Visual Studio Online provide us fo free. We will cover the Continuous Integration and the Continuous Deployment to the Cloud (Azure but not only) going deep into the brand new build system.

author.bio: With over 12 years of experience in software development and IT, Davide Benvegnù is the Director and CTO of DBTek Ltd and the former International Development Manager for Aruba.it. Currently he is responsible for the management of software development and all other company technical activities, he works with Azure and acts as a consultant in the field of ALM (Application Lifecycle Management). In the 2015 he has been awarded with the Microsoft MVP in Visual Studio ALM. In the past, in addition to software development, has also managed and coordinated the systems administration and dealt with virtualization and consolidation of entire Data Centers. He is a member of the staff of DotNetToscana, an official Microsoft Technical Community, where he helps to organize events and does some speeches to technical conferences about .Net and Microsoft technology stack. He is also a member of GetLatestVersion, the Italian community about ALM. Indeed, he has held several sessions and talks to events of national relevance, such as Community Days, SMAU, Festival ICT and many others.

proposal.title: Advanced Web Application Monitoring with Application Insights
proposal.description: Do you want to know how many users browse your web application? Do you need to understand how they are using it? Do you want to investigate about performances, exceptions, events and so on? Let's see how to retrieve all these informations (and so much more) using Azure Application Insights. We will have an overview of the tool and then we will go advanced and see how to customize it to fulfill our needs.

author.bio: With over 12 years of experience in software development and IT, Davide Benvegnù is the Director and CTO of DBTek Ltd and the former International Development Manager for Aruba.it. Currently he is responsible for the management of software development and all other company technical activities, he works with Azure and acts as a consultant in the field of ALM (Application Lifecycle Management). In the 2015 he has been awarded with the Microsoft MVP in Visual Studio ALM. In the past, in addition to software development, has also managed and coordinated the systems administration and dealt with virtualization and consolidation of entire Data Centers. He is a member of the staff of DotNetToscana, an official Microsoft Technical Community, where he helps to organize events and does some speeches to technical conferences about .Net and Microsoft technology stack. He is also a member of GetLatestVersion, the Italian community about ALM. Indeed, he has held several sessions and talks to events of national relevance, such as Community Days, SMAU, Festival ICT and many others.

proposal.title: Experimenting with ServiceWorker
proposal.description: Service Worker is a promising web game changer, by basically introducing a new layer between the page and the server it allows developers to implement a new interesting array of front-end features, starting from a proper offline experience to template compilation, routing, data interpolation and more. This talk introduces this technology and shows what a Service Worker is and how it works, then it took a step forward and examines a few interesting 'edge' use cases such as template compilation, format conversion (from XML to JSON) and push notifications.

author.bio: Sandro Paganotti is Front-End Developer at Guardian News and Media, author of “Designing next generation web Projects with CSS3” for Packt Publishing and technical trainer for Avanscoperta. He loves 60fps web interfaces, frontend automation and offline-first web apps.

proposal.title: Feedback loops
proposal.description: Agile. Agile is not a noun we can quantify but an adjective. Why on earth are most people trying to buy some ’agile’ then ? Why are people trying to sell that they are ’doing’ agile? Maybe it's time to remember the core values of software development, and among them, feedback is a central one. Let’s try to refine our ability to understand feedback and see how it can help to produce better software

author.bio: Rui Carvalho is a software craftsman with strong experience in .net and web applications. He tries to help people building better software most of it's time but also to inspire students with clean code during it's teaching time. He runs the Alt.Net france community and he also created the professional developer's conference NCRAFTS.io
